Award.AwardTitle: Marine Technology Mentoring and Internship Program on Oceanographic Research Vessels
Award.AbstractNarration: The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center will continue its marine technical internship program, which represents a partnership with University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) and the United States Coast Guard (USCG). The program will provide 14 undergraduate students with two to eight week internships and one student with a six-month internship each year for the next three years (2014-2017). MATE interns work with marine technicians and scientists onboard UNOLS and USCG research vessels, and these experiences provide them with the opportunity to develop their technical, scientific, seamanship, and interpersonal skills. MATE's at-sea technical internships help undergraduate students gain the experience they need to be qualified for technical jobs in marine-related academic and industry careers, and it provides ocean-related employers with access to qualified technical professionals who can fill their workforce needs. The MATE Center has 56 formal community college and university partnerships from which the interns are actively recruited. The program targets community college students enrolled in marine science and technology programs and university students interested in marine technical careers. The program's primary target audience is students enrolled in community colleges as these students tend to be more diverse (age, socioeconomic and ethnic) than four-year university students and are not typically provided with research opportunities. Evaluation into the success of the internship's long-term impact on student career trajectories is planned. Through this work, the internship program continues to expand its reach and impact on undergraduate marine technical education.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center's marine technical internship provides college and university students with the opportunity to learn what it takes to become a marine technician (http://www.marinetech.org/internships). Marine technicians are individuals that apply basic seamanship, science, computer, and engineering skills to the marine environment. Marine technicians play an important role in the collection of scientific measurements that allow us to understand how the oceans work and to use the ocean and its resources more safely and wisely.  Gaining the knowledge and skills needed to become a marine technician is challenging for students because it is prohibitively expensive for most college and university programs to offer substantial time at sea working with state-of-the-art equipment.

To address this challenge, the MATE Center started the At-Sea internship program in 1999 and to date has placed 360 students in at-sea and shore-based internship positions. This grant provided funding for 42 interns from 29 colleges and universities to work aboard 13 different research vessels. Interns work with marine technicians, scientists and engineers; this allows interns to develop their technical, scientific, seamanship, and interpersonal skills.  Internships last between two weeks and six months, and interns are provided with fully paid travel expenses and a stipend.  Most of the at-sea internships are aboard University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) and U.S. Coast Guard vessels.  For the UNOLS fleet, the At-Sea internship program is the main method used for recruiting and hiring new talent.

In a recent survey of former MATE interns (n = 91), 90% claimed their Internship was a major contributing factor in obtaining employment, being accepted into a higher degree program, or receiving a scholarship or other award.  They feel the experience helped them focus on a specific career path, and as a result of being given this opportunity, many have been offered new opportunities in the field of marine technology. Overall, the interns believe completing the internship has helped them make concrete decisions about their career path, develop professionally, and gain valuable, marketable skills that help them successfully compete in the workforce.


Last Modified: 09/25/2019
Modified by: Deidre Sullivan
